question: Who makes Go-Pods?
answer:
Go-Pods are manufactured in Portugal and have been in production for over 25 years!


Red Lion Caravan Centre are the sole importer and distributor of Go-Pods in the United Kingdom, though we also have a gradually expanding dealership network in the European Union.

 

We hope to establish partnerships with other caravan dealers across the globe in coming years.

 

If you're visiting this website from outside of the UK, please head to our international website, www.Go-Pod.com to find a list of our current dealers.

question: Where can I view a Go-Pod?
answer:
There are a few ways to view a Go-Pod:

  • In person at the Red Lion Caravans showroom in Southport, Lancashire.
    Showroom viewings
  • Online with a member of our sales team.
    Online viewings
  • Visit us at a show or event we're attending.
    Shows & events
  • At any of our 80+ owner viewing locations.
    View with an owner

question: Can I buy a Go-Pod from anywhere else?
answer:
Red Lion Caravans in Southport, Lancashire, are the only official dealer of Go-Pods in the UK.

We also have a number of dealers in the EU.

EU dealer map

question: Who are Go-Pods suited to?
answer:
We have a wide and diverse range of customers who are drawn to Go-Pods for many reasons. Here are just a few:

  • Campers upgrading from tents.
  • Owners downsizing from larger, traditional touring caravans who appreciate the convenience and ease of use-often with the bonus of being able to store a Go-Pod at home.
  • Solo travellers who don't need the space of a larger caravan.
  • Caravan enthusiasts aged 60+ who may find big caravans harder to manage.
  • Drivers with smaller-engine vehicles that can't tow heavy caravans.
  • Busy professionals who love being able to head off on adventures at short notice.

These are just a few examples-the truth is that anyone, of any age, can benefit from a Go-Pod!

question: What are the main advantages of Go-Pods vs other caravans?
answer:
Go-Pods offer many advantages over other micro tourers, lightweight leisure vehicles, and traditional caravans. Here are just a few:

  • The one-piece GRP fibreglass shell has no seams or joins, unlike traditional caravans built with separate panels. This means there's very little possibility of water ingress or damage.
  • The GRP fibreglass shell is extremely lightweight, providing greater fuel economy and allowing the Go-Pod to be towed with smaller cars.
  • The aerodynamic body shape reduces wind resistance.
  • Go-Pods are compact and easy to store-fitting inside most standard garages. The seating area converts into a double bed, saving space and allowing flexible configurations.
  • Many components can be used without access to a 230v supply, allowing 'off-grid' use. This saves money on campsite pitches and enables travel to locations that other caravans can't reach.
  • There are multiple options for aesthetic customisation-furniture and fabric colours, custom gel coat colours, vinyl graphics, and more.
  • Go-Pods are easy to service and maintain, requiring far less annual maintenance than most caravans.
  • There's a thriving community of Go-Pod owners worldwide-an invaluable resource where members gladly share advice and assistance.

If you'd like to read about the specific advantages of a Go-Pod versus a small campervan (e.g. Volkswagen T5 models), click the button below.

Go-Pods vs Camper Vans

question: Can Go-Pods be used throughout the year?
answer:
They certainly can!

With around 1.5-2 cm of insulation, Go-Pods are incredibly effective at maintaining a constant temperature.

Dual-fuel blown-air heating systems are available as an optional extra. They run on either gas or 240V mains electricity, meaning they can be used both on- and off-grid.

question: Where can I store a Go-Pod?
answer:
Go-Pods will fit comfortably in most standard-size garages, meaning they can be stored at home, saving money on storage fees.

At only 4.20 m in length, they are roughly the size of a standard hatchback car, so some customers store them in residential parking spaces and underground garages.

Dimensions

question: Can I use my Go-Pod off-grid (without access to mains electricity)?
answer:
Go-Pods are extremely versatile and can be used without access to mains (240V) electricity supply.

They include as standard:

  • 12V 85Ah leisure battery (110Ah upgrade available)
  • Dometic CRE50 compressor refrigerator (powered by the onboard leisure battery)
  • 2-burner gas hob.

Optional extras include:

  • 100W solar panel to provide charge to the leisure battery.
  • Propex dual-fuel blown-air heating system, able to run on either gas or 240V.
Optional extras

question: What is a "motor mover" and what does it do?
answer:
A motor mover is an electrical, mechanical unit that allows you to manoeuvre a caravan using a remote control.

This is how it works:

Units are installed at either end of the axle(s), beside the wheels. Cogs engage and press against the wheels of your caravan. When you press directional buttons on the remote control, the cogs move either backwards or forwards, depending on the buttons you press.

This allows you to move your caravan backwards, forwards, turn in either direction, or move diagonally.

We install the Powrtouch Freedom automatic motor mover units on Go-Pods.

What's the difference between a manual and automatic motor mover?

The only difference is how the cogs engage with the wheels of your caravan. Manual versions require you to use a winder or crank to move the cogs from their resting position to engage with the wheels, whereas automatic versions take care of this process for you when activated.

Manual versions are usually slightly cheaper, but there isn't a huge difference in cost.

Motor mover guide

question: How can I place an order for a Go-Pod?
answer:
To order a Go-Pod, give us a call on 01234 816 832 or send an email to sales@go-pods.co.uk.

Alternatively, visit our showroom at Red Lion Caravan Centre, Southport, Lancashire.

If you're viewing this website from outside the UK and there isn't yet a Go-Pods dealer in your country, you can order directly from us for collection from our factory in Portugal, or we can arrange delivery to your home for an extra charge.

Please contact us for more details.

question: Do Go-Pods come with a warranty?
answer:
They do indeed!

Go-Pods purchased directly from us include a 12-month back-to-base warranty as standard. There is also the option to upgrade this to a 36-month nationwide warranty for £399.00.

Go-Pod Pioneer models include the 36-month nationwide warranty as standard.

What's the difference between the "back-to-base" warranty and the 36-month nationwide version?

"Back-to-base" means that, in the event of a warranty claim, you'd need to bring your Go-Pod back to us for the work to be completed.

The nationwide warranty is administered by a third-party company, The Motoring Organisation. In the event of a warranty claim, you'd contact them directly and they will arrange for the necessary work to be completed at a local approved workshop. In some cases (for example, if the caravan isn't safe for towing) they'll even arrange for your Go-Pod to be collected and delivered back to you after the work is completed.

Do any of the individual appliances or components include their own warranty?

Yes, many of the components and appliances fitted in Go-Pods include their own warranties. For example, the sink/hob units and refrigerators are manufactured by Dometic and include manufacturer-backed warranties.

If any of these components were to fail, you should contact us and we'll lodge a warranty claim with our supplier, who will in turn lodge it with the manufacturer. Usually, our supplier will obtain a warranty replacement from the manufacturer and send it to us, and we'll book your Go-Pod into our workshop to install the replacement.

Warranty documents

question: Where do I collect my Go-Pod?
answer:
Collection is from Red Lion Caravan Centre in Southport, Lancashire.

Collection details

question: Do you offer delivery?
answer:
Yes! Home delivery is available from £2.00 per mile, charged one way.

We calculate this based on the distance from our premises (postcode PR8 5LF) to your delivery postcode, using the shortest route shown on Google Maps. Check our delivery & collection page for a handy calculator to help you work out likely delivery charges.

However, we encourage customers to collect where possible, especially those new to caravanning. Collecting from us ensures you'll receive a thorough and detailed handover presentation from our knowledgeable team.

Delivery calculator

question: If I choose delivery, will I receive a handover?
answer:
We use an external delivery partner in the UK, and their drivers are not trained to provide Go-Pod handovers.

For that reason, we recommend that customers opt for collection where possible instead - in particular customers who do not have any prior caravanning experience.

question: Do I need to bring a number plate with me?
answer:
Ideally, yes.

However, we do offer number plate printing on site for an additional fee.

To do so, you will need to bring your driving license and V5C for us to verify that you are the registered keeper of the vehicle.

question: Do I need insurance for my Go-Pod?
answer:
Insurance isn't legally required for caravans, but it's strongly recommended so that you're covered in the event of an accident.

Insurance premiums vary depending on several factors, including:

  • Your personal details.
  • Where you'll be storing the Go-Pod (premiums are typically higher if it's kept on public roads or other easily accessible places).
  • Rates of caravan theft in your area.
  • The security items fitted to your Go-Pod. Most insurers require at least a hitch lock box and wheel clamp. Other items, such as smart tracker devices, can help reduce your premiums considerably.

Go-Pods are partnered with Caravan Guard, the leading insurer of leisure vehicles in the UK and the first to offer comprehensive policies for Go-Pods.

Caravan Guard offer a special 14-day free towaway cover to all Go-Pod customers who purchase directly from us, with no obligation to accept their quotation for full coverage. Ask your salesman when ordering or select the option to accept the offer if ordering via our website.

question: How do I register my Go-Pod with CRiS?
answer:
All of our pre-owned Go-Pods are registered with CRiS and will be transferred into your name on your handover day.

From 2026, all brand new Go-Pod stock models will also be preregistered with CRiS, saving you the hassle.

question: How are Go-Pods manufactured?
answer:
Go-Pods are relatively unique caravans, as they have a one-piece GRP fibreglass shell with no seams or joins. This prevents water ingress and extends the longevity of the caravan.

Our patented shell design is produced by a fibreglass manufacturer using a mould. Fibreglass is poured into the mould and allowed to set. A gel coat is applied atop the fibreglass shell to provide an aesthetically pleasing finish.

We build the body of the Go-Pods at our factory, using a galvanised steel chassis as the base. We then place the shell onto the chassis and begin fitting the interior of the Go-Pod.

The frame is constructed with wood (which helps to keep the weight down) and the cavities are filled with medium density polystyrene insulation blocks. This helps to retain heat in the colder months, and keep the Go-Pod cool during the summer months. White lacquered MDF wall panels are then placed over the frame and insulation.

The floor (and under-floor) is made from marine-grade plywood, which is water resistant and helps to prevent against water ingress from road water. It is securely sealed around the edges using high quality caravan sealant.

Interior furniture units are made from strong poplar plywood.

question: Can my car tow a Go-Pod?
answer:
The vast majority of vehicles can tow a Go-Pod with ease, thanks to their low overall weight and aerodynamic shape.

With a maximum weight (MTPLM) of just 750 kg and a factory standard weight (MiRO) of 580 kg, almost any vehicle can tow a Go-Pod - including small hatchbacks, EVs, and even some trikes.

Check if your vehicle is suitable for towing a Go-Pod:

Method 1 - V5C / logbook

This is the easiest way to check if your vehicle is capable of towing a Go-Pod (or any caravan, for that matter).

Open your green V5C (logbook) document for your vehicle and look on the first inside page. Under the heading "O: Technical permissible maximum towable mass of trailer", find the sub-heading "O.1: braked (kg)".

As long as the figure displayed next to this sub-heading is 750 kg or more, your car can tow a Go-Pod.

Method 2 - VIN plate

If you don't have your V5C to hand, you can manually calculate your towing allowance by checking the VIN plate of your vehicle.

This is a metal-stamped plate, usually affixed to the inside of either the engine compartment or one of the door openings. On the VIN plate, three figures (in kilograms) will be displayed:

  • The first figure is the Gross Vehicle Weight - the total weight of your vehicle, unladen.
  • The second figure is the Gross Train Weight - the maximum allowed weight of your vehicle and a trailer, both fully laden.
  • The third figure is the Axle Weight - not relevant for what we're trying to achieve.

To calculate the braked towing allowance of your vehicle, simply subtract the Gross Vehicle Weight from the Gross Train Weight.

question: What towing equipment is required?
answer:
You need a standard 50mm diameter tow ball and 13 pin Euro socket electrics.

This socket will accept the Go-Pods 13 pin plug which works the towing lights, charges the on-board battery and powers the fridge in transit*

If your tow vehicle has twin electrics you can buy an adaptor to convert the leads. If you have only 7 pin electrics on your car, you can still tow with an adaptor but it will only operate the driving lights & won't power anything else.

You do not require an AL-KO branded tow bar and non branded tow bars are fine to fit.

*Newer Go-Pods include a 12v, front-opening compressor refrigerator. This runs from the on-board leisure battery, so will operate whenever you need it (as long as it's turned on).

question: Do I need extended towing mirrors?
answer:
When towing, the law requires that drivers have adequate view to the rear of the trailer/caravan in tow.

With the Go-Pod, most vehicle's existing side mirrors allow for a good view along the entire side of the caravan and extension mirrors are usually not required.

question: What tyre sizes are suitable for Go-Pods?
answer:
The standard tyre size for all Go-Pods (including those with an upgraded chassis rating of 1000 kg) is 175/70 R13 86N.

A suitable alternative for Go-Pods with a chassis rating of 750 kg is 175/70 R13 82T.

Tech specs

question: What should the tyre pressure be?
answer:
Go-Pod tyres should be inflated to a pressure of 35 psi.

Tech specs

question: What are the torque settings for Go-Pod wheels?
answer:
The wheel nut torque is 65lbs for standard wheels and 95lbs for alloys.

Tech specs

question: Which gas bottles are suitable for Go-Pods?
answer:
There are a number of suitable gas bottles on the market for use with Go-Pods. The most common is a Calor Gas 3.9 kg propane bottle.

Click the button below to visit our "Tech Specs" page showing all of the compatible bottles.

Tech specs

question: Where can I have my Go-Pod serviced?
answer:
If you're not able to bring your Go-Pod to the workshop at Red Lion Caravan Centre for servicing, you can use any NCC-approved workshop.

NCC approved workshops

question: Where can I find my chassis number?
answer:
Your chassis number can be found on a stamped metal plate that is riveted to the draw bar at the front of your Go-Pod. The longest number on the plate is your chassis number.

The chassis number is required to insure your Go-Pod and register it with CRiS.

question: What does 'MiRO' mean?
answer:
MiRO stands for Mass In Running Order.

It's sometimes referred to as the 'factory weight' or 'unladen weight' of a caravan or trailer.

This is essentially the weight of a Go-Pod without any personal effects, additional equipment or passengers inside.

question: What does 'MTPLM' mean?
answer:
MTPLM stands for Maximum Technically Permissible Laden Mass.

This is the total weight (set by the manufacturer) that a caravan/trailer cannot exceed when fully laden.

The MTPLM is sometimes referred to as the 'MAM', or Maximum Authorised Mass.

To ascertain whether your vehicle can tow a caravan, you should compare the MTPLM figure to your vehicles 'braked towing allowance', which can be found in your V5C (logbook) document.

If the 'braked towing allowance' matches or exceeds the MTPLM of the caravan, you can legally tow it.

question: What does 'Payload' mean?
answer:
The payload of a caravan/trailer is simply the available weight for personal effects and supplies.

You can find the payload of a caravan or trailer by subtracting the MiRO (Mass in Running Order) from the MTPLM (Maximum Technically Permissible Laden Mass).

question: What does 'Nose weight' mean?
answer: Nose weight is the weight or downward force from the caravan's hitch to the tow car's tow ball.
